awd_titl_txt: Probing Eectroweak Symmetry Breaking and Searches for New Physics at the LHC with the ATLAS Experiment
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will provide support to a new group working on the ATLAS experiment at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN, a particle physics laboratory in Geneva, Switzerland. The LHC machine and ATLAS, a large particle detector facility, were built as basic science tools using funds from NSF and other agencies around the world. One of their primary objectives was to find the Higgs Boson, the last particle in the historically successful "Standard Model" (SM) that accounts for so much of the existence of, and forces between, known particles forming the matter in the universe. This effort has been successful. The next step in the experiments is to look for evidence for physics Beyond the Standard Model (BSM) that might, for instance, account for the presence of the mysterious "Dark Matter" that makes up so much of the mass of the universe. The LHC is currently in the midst of Run 2, at almost twice the energy explored earlier and with significantly increased event samples. It is possible that evidence for BSM physics could emerge at this higher energy and with the higher event statistics. Search for evidence of such physics is the goal of this project.

The California State University East Bay high energy physics group will use data collected by the ATLAS experiment to probe the mechanism by which fundamental particles acquire mass through electroweak symmetry breaking (EWSB) and to search for evidence of new physics.  The group will search for pairs of Higgs bosons and other exotic particles decaying to pairs of b-quarks and pairs of tau leptons.  Study of such rare events has become more viable as the center-of-mass energy of the LHC is increased to 14 TeV and the luminosity of the accelerator facility is steadily increased.  In parallel, upgrades of the ATLAS detector are underway which will allow for further improvements in data recording.   The Cal State East Bay group will focus on reconstruction of particle tracks and their association with primary collision vertices, important for the identification and measurement of the b-quarks and tau leptons in complex particle interactions.  Collaboration is planned with the ATLAS group at the SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory to work on the upgrade of the ATLAS Fast TracKer (FTK), instrumentation that facilitates fast charged-particle track finding used in triggering.

This research program will bring the excitement and study of high energy physics to Cal State East Bay, which is recognized as a university with one of the most diverse undergraduate student enrollments in the country.    Students in the group will participate in collaborative science,  data analysis, and in instrumentation testing at the group's campus laboratories and at SLAC and CERN.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The work done under this award, studying the production of two Higgs bosons in collisions at the ATLAS experiment, has contributed to our goal of better understanding the moment in the early universe called Electroweak Symmetry Breaking, when the Electromagnetic Force split apart from the Weak Nuclear Force.  

Electroweak Symmetry Breaking caused the particles associated with the weak force, the W and the Z bosons, to gain mass, making them very different from the photon, the particle associated with the electromagnetic force.  We are studying this process by measuring the rate that Higgs bosons are produced in pairs at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN.  Some of the questions we are trying to answer are: Did this process happen in the simplest way possible, as is currently predicted in the Standard Model of particle physics, or did nature do something a little more complicated at that moment in the early universe? And: Are there other particles that can also produce two Higgs bosons at the same time? We have so far been able to rule out some of the more exotic theories that could produce a large number of Higgs boson pairs. These include some theories that predict that Gravity could produce a quantum mechanical particle, the graviton, that could decay into two Higgs bosons. (Though variations of this theory may still be possible.) The current results rule out any new physics producing 3.1 times more Higgs pairs than the Standard Model predicts.

Measuring the rate that Higgs bosons are produced in pairs involves precise modeling of the predicted particles that are produced in the LHC.  This modeling is a large portion of the work to analyze Higgs pair production. It requires Monte Carlo statistical modeling and machine learning.  It also requires a careful understanding of the ATLAS detector.  A portion of the work done under this award is devoted to understanding how the detector changes as it is bombarded with high energy ionizing radiation.

We will be able to say more definitely whether electroweak symmetry breaking happened as predicted by the Standard Model after the LHC is upgraded and can produce a vastly larger amount of data.  A portion of the work done under this award is preparing for the upgrade in the LHC (planned for 2029) by building an improved ATLAS detector. 

All aspects of this work involved undergraduate researchers from California State University East Bay. Students contributed to data analysis, learned to program in Python and C++, to run Monte Carlo generators, and to tune machine learning algorithms.  They also made major contributions to the hardware work of upgrading the ATLAS detector.  Cal State East Bay is noted to be the most diverse university in the lower 48 states, and student researchers from Cal State East Bay are actively changing the make-up of particle physics.

The PI of this award has a strong interest in sharing particle physics with the public and bringing new people into the field.  One avenue of sharing particle physics comes through PhysicsCakes, an endeavor that raises interest in particle physics in new demographics with cake. PhysicsCakes reaches the public through Twitter and Facebook and at public events, and is often highlighted by news media. Cakes with particle physics themes are tweeted on notable days; for example, the chocolate lava nuclear potential cake, modeled after alpha emission in Uranium 238, on Marie Curie's birthday, and the Rainbow Physics Equations Cake LGBTQ STEM Day. At science festivals, the PI hosts a Proton Cookie booth, where people can create edible protons with M&M quarks and "gluon" frosting. Physics cakes have been highlighted in the New York Times, Symmetry Magazine, Forbes, La Republica, a national daily Italian newspaper, and briefly in The New Yorker. The last line of the La Republica article says (translated), "For skeptics who wonder why money is spent in order to search for bosons, quarks, and other tiny particles, a cake provides the answer: such exploration serves to find the recipe through which the universe was created. And it all tastes delicious."

 


Last Modified: 11/29/2022
Modified by: Kathryn Grimm
